text: I also like the version with 4k or 5k.
<@U026E0ZNR> Does it help the interactivity at all if the user simply opens the drawer if they try to interact with the animation?

it comes down to a matter of how the new badges get introduced if the user interrupts the preview list items before they snap back under the header bar. currently they rely completely on that snapping action and i can’t figure out how they would show up if that didn’t get to finish

I probably should have shared this a lot earlier, but better late than never. I know that this is a lot of y’all’s first iOS project, so I thought I’d share this “designer’s guide” to iOS. While I encourage EVERYONE to read and immerse themselves in the HIG, this is a helpful distillation of key points <http://ivomynttinen.com/blog/ios-design-guidelines>

attachments.title: The iOS Design Guidelines - Ivo Mynttinen / User Interface Designer
attachments.text: Designing iOS apps can be difficult sometimes, but finding correct and up-to-date information about all of Apples’ devices shouldn’t be.
attachments.fallback: Ivo Mynttinen / User Interface Designer: The iOS Design Guidelines - Ivo Mynttinen / User Interface Designer

text: and a link to the HIG: <https://developer.apple.com/ios/human-interface-guidelines/>

attachments.title: iOS Human Interface Guidelines
attachments.text: Learn about designing apps for iOS.

text:
Here’s an update on the new activity/badge addition stuff. It’s a bit of a departure from the full on “garage door” idea but this is 1) much more dev and user friendly, 2) infinitely scalable with more or less activities in a single batch adding event, and 3) more resolved as far as choreography goes. Let me know how you all respond. I personally feel it could be a bit snappier when each badge hops upward (not necessarily quicker).

<https://www.dropbox.com/s/wbofbiladf5c270/160901_ActivityBar_New_01.mov?dl=0>
makes a lot of sense to me
